data.text: How Do You Keep Your Phone Charged More Than a Day when Long-Distance Cycle Touring?

How do people keep their phone on charge for more than a day without plugging on mains ? I have a front dynamo 6v 3 w with my phone on charge and the charge keeps falling throughout the day with nearly nothing at the end of day. I must admit the screen is nearly on max brightness so I can see it in the sun. I am not connected to media/internet while cycling and my maps are downloaded to avoid internet connection. Thank for any help ..
Good backup battery connected to portable solar power attached to the top of my bag in the back rack
data.author: Ian Wills

data.text: I use a powerpack lsts for 2.5 full recharges
data.author: Scott Fowler

data.text: I second the external battery. Mine can charge my phone about 4 times or my tablet twice. I carry a 2-port charger and cables and recharge both the battery pack and the phone or tablet whenever I can - including in restaurants and sometimes outside gas stations.
data.author: Brian Huntley

data.text: Clean up your phone functionality, turn off your screen, check it intermittently, dont run it all day.
data.author: Sheila Anderson

data.text: I have a 20 000mAh battery bank. There are very cheap ones out there that are compact (about 4x4x 1/2 inch) and work just as well as the expensive ones. 20 000mAh will charge an iphone 3 times and most regular phones 5 times.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text:
Have used a Wahoo Elment - much lower battery use than phone. Plus battery and Xdragon 20w solar worked really well. https://www.outdoorgearlab.com/reviews/camping-and-hiking/solar-charger/x-dragon-20w
X-Dragon 20W Review
outdoorgearlab.com
data.author: Greg Harvey

data.text: Solar panel or I have a 20,000mAh power bank. They charge at similar levels.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Your phone being exposed to so much heat, i.e. long usage and sunlight, will also degrade your phone and battery over time. Keep them shaded.
data.author: James Johnston

data.text: Running your phone in airplane mode still keeps the gps running and will work with downloading maps but draws far less power. Ultimate a cell phone isn‚Äôt great for all day navigation. A stand alone gps will easily last the whole day, takes less power to charge up, and allows you to keep your phone off to turn on when you need it.
data.author: Grahame Joy

data.text: Solar panel to a 20,000mAh bank. But honestly, charging electronics in hot weather can also make it to where they won‚Äôt charge well unfortunately.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: I switched to an Anker battery. Keeps iPhone and gps going for 2 full days without charging.
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: All of the above. Phone screen will use lots of power. In term of charging, son hub through k-lite usb, charges my ageing iPhone 6 about 50% over 2 hrs at average 20 kph, and starts to charge the iPhone at about 7 kph
data.author: David Podger

data.text: iPhones, in particular, (not sure about other phones) are notoriously difficult to charge using a Dyno-USB charger. There are a few brands reported to work better than others. As others have alluded, you can charge a power bank and then use it to charge your phone.
data.author: John Jarvis

data.text:
the issue of many phones: there is a handshake between power source and phone. Then the power should be stable, or another handshake is needed. If the power/voltage is too low the phone will be discharged. See some more info from Alee‚Äôs https://www.cyclingabout.com/rim-dynamos-can-now-generate-more-power-than-hub-dynamos/ or www.pedalcell.com/reviews And iPhone have a tremendous advantage: www.mapout.app : most compact offline map, and with elevation profiles, one time 5‚Ç¨ ü§ìü§ì‚ù§Ô∏è
Rim Dynamos Can Now Generate 70% MORE Power Than Hub Dynamos - CyclingAbout
cyclingabout.com
data.author: Georges Froidevaux

data.text: Solar panel on my basket or on my trailer,depends on my setup. Than I charge my power bank, that's again charging whatever I want.But to be honest not always works perfect but I think better than dynamo hub.
data.author: Thore Burapa Pedersen

data.text: I've found that a dynamo is a good way to charge a battery, but not the phone itself. Get a power bank that does passthrough charging like Voltaic. The hub charges the battery while the battery charges the phone. I use a solar panel as well because why not
data.author: Gerald Prokop

data.text: Agree. I charge battery pack while riding, then use it to charge phone when stopped.
data.author: Mark Self

data.text:
exactly: if the tension or amperage gets too low (aka not fast enough) it might even discharge the phone. A powerbank has a loss of 10-30%‚Ä¶ a power capacitor will be more efficient, but keep less energy. See as well here: www.pedalcell.com/reviews
Reviews
pedalcell.com
data.author: Georges Froidevaux

data.text: Good info here. Your dynohub may be cutting off charging if you're going too slow--there's apparently a technical fix for that--in the U.S., Peter White Cycles is an authority and could assist. Shifting to a Wahoo Bolt would also make sense, and I think you'd find it less cumbersome as a navigation aid than a smart phone. For short trips, a power bank type battery works really well. Likewise a solar panel over the rear panniers--plenty of people use a solar panel to charge their powerbank and then have ample power for use during the evening.
data.author: M Sebastian Richard Williams

data.text: I have a 10w Voltaic solar panel‚Ä¶charged my phone and iPad- was able to use in-the-fky
data.author: Val Boggs

data.text: 20w solar panel and a 25k mah power bank
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: Found these on Amazon. $35 bucks work great . I keep them in my bags
data.author: Rick Shaffer
Robbie

data.text: Would fit nicely in a cocktail! ;-)
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: When I need to conserve my phone battery, I run in airplane mode with downloaded maps and use mostly voice navigation prompts from Komoot, checking the screen as needed. I also carry an Anchor power bank that I can trickle charge from my dynamo hub.
data.author: Todd Burgman

data.text: Yup, the same. Also switch all apps you can to dark mode. And disable any background anything. Power saving on too, obvs.
data.author: Birgit Le Blond

data.text: I have an ebike, I can ride all day with full internet map guidance on.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: Get an extra phone, or 2 or 3... üòÇ
data.author: Lawrence Liang

data.text: I use a Anker battery pack ,it will re charge my phone at least 6 times .
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: With front dynamo you must pedal 15+km/h, hence go solar, will send √† review later on, the best are Anker, but out of stock in Europe, buy MONOCRISTALLIN
data.author: Georges Augusto

data.text: 2x Anker battery pack (aka powerbanks): 13000 mAh + 26800 mAh can keep me going for two weeks. iPhone SE (small screen = small energy consumption). Plus Garmin Edge for navigation, which uses less power than a smartphone.
data.author: Marcin Kysiak

data.text: Completely off (bigger devices) and the smaller one on airplane mode and using MapsMe. That way it lasts longer. I also often draw the main points and lines of the route on a small card for my shirt pocket and thus only resort to the smart phone GPS when really needed. I'll charge my 2.5 powerbanka along the way at coffee shops etc...or at hostels. Then I also have a small solar panel but that really requires sunny days and long breaks, which is ok in summer.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: But I don't charge the devices directly from the solar panels. So first panel to powerbank, then power bank to device. Takes more time ,kind of inconvenient, but who's in a hurry? During the day charge the powerbanks only with the solar panels somewhere along the road (but not while riding), or charge everything while in a coffee shop, etc., and at night charge devices from the listenable for the next day.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Solar panel, charge a battery pack when mains are available, aurplane mode, don't keep your screen on so much.
data.author: Wilhelm Mellerg√•rd

data.text: I use my phone for photographs and keep it on airplane mode during the day with occasional check ins when i stop for a break. For route finding, i use a garmin gps30 which will last 2 days on good quality AA batteries and, 1.5 days on my usb rechargeable AA batteries. I also carry a small map or road atlas on the multi day rides. When off grid, i carry 3 small power banks that will easily keep my phone charged. I have a selection of solar panels ranging from 10 to 30w that i use for charging the power banks, AA batteries, gopro, bike lights etc ( the phone does not charge well from the panels. I sometimes also carry a bit of ham radio equipment ,hence the need for extra powerbanks as, one of the radios requires 12v. The solar panels are small and light and, are easily fitted onto my pannier bags and my tent. If i want, i could mount 5 panels that way but, 3 should suffice. When i stop at a hotel, i charge the lot up via usb as, I also pack a couple of 5 port usb mains chargers.
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: As some comments above, the dynamo should be fine if you have it in airplane mode, with just a gps app running for navigation and only turning the screen on occasionally to check location rather than screen on continually. I can easily run my iPhone for over a day without any recharging in this mode. If you then have a 20,000mA power bank you can charge overnight every 3-4 days as backup then you shouldn‚Äôt have any problems.
data.author: Nigel Blandford

data.text: I have a portable battery that I keep in the frame bag. Keep my phone connected all day‚Ä¶
data.author: Karen Donnelly

data.text: Looks like a few people have suggested charging a battery and plugging your phone in to that.
data.author: Myles Blackwood

data.text: Turn it off when you don‚Äôt need it - which is most of the time, really. I would make turn notes, on paper - to keep me on track - and only turn it on when needed. If limit you use a full charge will last quite a while.
data.author: Elizabeth Cage

data.text: Powerbanks and solarpanels the 6v3w isnt enough for a phone its enough for light and or a bike computer at best u need a 6w front dynamo hub or try the pedalcell i use both the pedalcell and a son hub with forumsladers charger for the double whammie when winter touring in the other 3 seasons its solar panel and powerbanks i usually carry 4x30.000 mah and 2x28 watt solar panels on the touring bike never need power from mains
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: I've been using a small Bluetooth handlebar speaker for several years now. I use voice navigation and put the phone away. Its the most efficient way I know for saving battery life. And I second what everyone else is saying, bring a battery pack. I usually have two, one on the dynamo and another for charging devices.
data.author: David Butterly

data.text: I use Huawei P40 for navigation whilst in the mountains, I switch to airplane mode, and it easily lasts 4-5 days.
data.author: Alan Ferrier

data.text: Either solar charger , which can easily overheat in hot countries or power bank
data.author: Aneta Venn

data.text: Turn off the phone location/navigation.
data.author: Mark Coffey

data.text: I noticed that if I marked the route before, that just following the GPS arrow vs having my phone do it for me, consumed so much less
data.author: Birgit Le Blond

data.text: anker powerbanks with quick charge are grear. i carry two 20000. i have a power hungry s7 edge. i get at least 4 charges per pack.
data.author: Ivan Gorodess

data.text: Use son dynamo to charge Garmin...use solar panel which I got in Spain from Decathlon for 25 euro to charge battery bank.i plan route on Garmin connect..transfer to Garmin Device...if I stop for coffee I use super charger to charge phone ..simples.The son dynamo runs lights if I travel at night to catch ferry's etc as well as charging Garmin . Self sufficient...it allows me to wild camp 90%of the timeüëçüè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å∑Û†Å¨Û†Å≥Û†Åø
data.author: Paul Williams

data.text: Do you use the phone for navigation? if so it will drain the battery, better to have a dedicated bike computer. Also I would charge a battery pack with the dynamo as charging the phone directly from the dynamo is not good for the phone's battery and its health due to the variations in the charging current.
data.author: Asif Raja Punjabi Cyclist

data.text: I would suggest you buy a Wahoo Roam ELEMNT it‚Äôs a solid product
data.author: Asif Raja Punjabi Cyclist

data.text: Start with a better phone that is capable of staying alive on standby for 2-3 days. My Pixel5 is an example. Turn off the screen when not needed, & wake it up only as long as needed. Get a more powerful charging source. My small folding solar panel produces up to 6w into my 10kmah power bank, & altogether probably weighs similar to your dynamo hub with no drag to overcome.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: Gotta love Uncle Sam Hacking and Tracking people.I can unplug mine and smoke a joint and a cigarette less than 10 minutes and I'll loose 20%charge
data.author: Ted Messer

data.text: I only use my mobile for r√©servations and urgencies. I have an extra power bank and use wifi to read mails when in restaurant. I also use paper maps. Just love them. Being on holyday also means off grid for me.
data.author: Sarah Delafortrie

data.text: 21w solar panel and 10,000mA battery
data.author: Eric Robertson

data.text: which brand and model do you have? i know, it is difficult to change it now for zou but i have a motorola defy and 3 days 72 hours is no problem....
data.author: Marian Ondas

data.text: It's the screen on full brightness that's draining the current.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text:
I use the dynamohub for daylight only. For recharging the phone: https://www.cyclingabout.com/rim-dynamos-can-now-generate-more-power-than-hub-dynamos/ Or www.pedalcell.com/reviews
Rim Dynamos Can Now Generate 70% MORE Power Than Hub Dynamos - CyclingAbout
cyclingabout.com
data.author: Georges Froidevaux

data.text: Take external batteries. We‚Äôve done it for hundreds of miles.
data.author: Clarke Prescott

data.text: I bring along a Freedom Battery that I use at night to power my CPAP machine.(I have sleep apnea)I have one Panier filled with that stuff. The battery is compact and weighs about 1 1/2 pounds. It recharges in about 4 hours. If you were just using it to recharge your phone and lights it would probably last all week.
data.author: Ed Weingarten

data.text: any link for this sir?
data.author: Simran Singh

data.text: I use a USB Power Bank and charge that from the dynamo while riding all day, and then by the end of the day it always has enough juice to put a full charge into my phone.
data.author: Hue Mann

data.text: Turn to plane mode , check for messages infrequently
data.author: Michael Bauermeister

data.text: I am looking to purchase a dynamo charger. Where do people get them? I have only checked Amazon so far.
data.author: Jonathon Horner

data.text: Muito obrigado everyone for all your answers, very helpful ..
data.author: Fernando Mendes
